document.docAuthor: Damme, Kay Van & Dumont, Henri J.
document.docTitle: Coronatella anemae Damme & Dumont, 2008, sp. n.
document.masterDocTitle: Further division of Alona Baird, 1843: separation and position of Coronatella Dybowski & Grochowski and Ovalona gen. n. (Crustacea: Cladocera)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Alona novae-zealandiae Sars
in Jenkin (1934) and Rey & St-Jean (1969)

Alona rectangula Sars
in
Dumont et al . (1984)

Type locality
. Canyon of Ghor Arbaat; series of samples in isolated rockpools with or without littoral fringe of
Typha angustifolia
, Red Sea Hills, near Port Sudan , Sudan . Note: we chose Sudan as type locality because Ekman (1904) was the first to find it here (identified as
Lynceus bukobensis
;
Fig. 5
in Ekman 1904 ; see Discussion). For more details on locality and a map, see
Dumont et al. (1984)
.

Material examined.
Type series.
Holotype
. One adult parthenogenetic female mounted in glass slide labelled “
Coronatella anemae
holotype ”; from type locality;
20.XII. 1981
, Leg. H.J. Dumont ;
Paratypes
. One adult parthenogenetic female and one adult male, slide labeled “
Coronatella anemae
paratypes ” same slide and data as holotype. Additional paratypes : tube containing mix of females, ephippia and males from type locality. All material deposited at the Royal Belgian Institute for Natural Sciences , Brussels ( RBIN ) under accession number IG 30.556
.

Additional material .
Material at UG Zooplankton Collection , Ghent University , Dpt. of Biology , Limnology Research Group. Sudan , 30 parthenogenetic females, 5 males , Canyon of Ghor Arbaat ; Red Sea Hills , near Port Sudan ,
20.XII.1981
,
Coll. H.J. Dumont ( Samples “ Sudan 18”,“21” in UGent Collection ). Socotra Island ( Yemen ), 50 parthenogenetic females from Qaysoh , permanent wetland South of Qalaansiyah (E- Socotra), K. Van Damme ,
17.I.2000
;
20 parthenogenetic females from Noged , small rock pools at entrance of Noged Cave (SE-Socotra), K. Van Damme ,
20.I.2000
;
60 parthenogenetic females, 20 males from Rewgid , culture from dried mud, series of rock pools in karstic limestone (NC-Socotra), details of habitat in
Van Damme et al . (2004)
. 15 Parthenogenetic females, small pond at entrance of administration building at Sharjah Breeding Centre , Sharjah , United Arab Emirates , Coll. K. Van Damme , 20.
VI .2006.
45 parthenogenetic females from Aldabra Island , Seychelles , Coll. K.G. McKenzie , ref. 1969.6.9.566–581 ( Natural History Museum , London ), 16 tubes. Uzbekistan , 3 parthenogenetic females. Mayalo Ricefield , Coll. I. Mirabdullaev ,
VIII.2000
.
Etymology . “anemae”, from “anema” (Lat. = wind), indicating dispersal by wind (noted on Socotra Island ; See Distribution).

Description of the adult parthenogenetic female. Habitus ( Figs 5A–B & 6 ). Medium-sized animals, 0.4–0.6mm , colourless and transparent. Specimens from Sudan ( Fig. 5B ) are relatively smaller ( 0.4–0.55mm ) than from Socotra Island ( 0.45–0.6mm ) ( Figs 5B & 6 ). In lateral view carapace rectangular with evenly curved dorsal margin and low posterodorsal angle. Ventral carapace margin rather straight in anterior half to slightly concave in posterior half ( Figs 5B , 6A ). Posteroventral corner with notch not well pronounced, close to posteroventral corner ( Fig. 5J ). In dorsal and ventral view, body relatively compressed ( Fig. 6D ) lacking a pronounced keel ( Fig 6B ). Head . Ocellus as large as eye ( Fig. 5A ). Head shield broad with rounded smooth posterior margin ( Figs 5D , 7A ). Rostrum blunt and short, aesthetascs projecting beyond its tip ( Fig. 5D ). Three main head pores ( Figs 6B , 7A ) of same size, narrowly connected, PP distance same as IP distance ( Fig. 7A ); main pores variable, overall relatively small with narrow connection, but broad in population from Rewgid, Socotra , Fig. 8H ; small pores closer to main pores than to lateral margin of head shield, at about 1.5 IP from the midline. In dorsal view, main head pores not elevated, but lateral pores in clear lateral depressions ( Figs 6A–C , 7A ). Strong variability in head pore size between three Socotran populations, from broad to narrow ( Fig. 8 ). Carapace ( Figs 5A–B , 6A–D ). Ornamentation consisting of parallel, well-developed wide striation, no fine striation; number of lines 18–20 ( Figs 5A–B , 6A–D ). Posterior margin wavy. This ornamentation also present on the head shield ( Fig. 6B ). Marginal setae in different groups, relatively longer group on frontal margin of carapace, followed by little shorter group in middle and medium sized group in posterior third of the margin ( Fig. 5B ). Marginal row of 35–40 (in large specimens up to 60) setae decreasing in size towards the posteroventral corner and followed by small spinules not arranged in groups ( Fig. 5J ). Labrum ( Figs 5G–I ). Labral keel in lateral view relatively short with moderately convex to wavy margin and obtuse tip ( Figs 5B&G–I ). No ventral setules or denticles on labral keel. Well pronounced lateral horns with anterior depressions on labrum ( Fig. 6D , between the bases of the antennae). Antennules ( Fig. 5E ). About 2.5– three times as long as wide, sensory seta short and implanted between 1/2d and 1/3d from apex. Three rows of fine setules on dorsal margin. Aesthetascs shorter by one fourth of antennular corm and subequal in length. Second antennae ( Figs 5F , 7B ). Coxal setae not studied. Coxal spine large, conical ( Fig. 5F ). Spinal formula 001/101, setal formula 113/003. First exopod seta on antenna long and narrow (exs 1 in Fig. 7B ), reaching beyond last antennal segments; on external side of second exopod segment, group of six to eight long spinules ( Fig. 7B ). Spine on first endopod segment as long as second endopod segment; main terminal spines on endo- and exopod well developed, as long as ultimate segment ( Figs 6F , 7B ). Terminal setae subequal in length and not reaching beyond dorsum of animal ( Fig. 6A ).

subSubSection.paragraph: First maxilla ( Fig. 9A ) with two long setulated setae.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Differential Diagnosis .
C. anemae
n.sp. can be recognized by a relatively long (2.5 to three times as long as wide) postabdomen, long slender basal spine (up to three times as long as basal thickness of basal claw), reaching half of claw length and with group of three to five long basal spinules. Anal margin straight, with pronounced triangular preanal corner protruding beyond postanal margin and postanal margin with eight to eleven marginal denticle groups, fascicles without thicker distal spinule. First endopodal antennal spine not reaching beyond segment. In
C. rectangula ,
postabdomen is shorter (two times as long as wide), with maximally seven marginal denticle groups and basal spine maximally one third of claw length. Diagnostic limb characters of
anemae
include IDL setae with setules or denticles but never with dominant heavy armature, reduced distal portion or chitineous ring as in
C. rectangula
. P2 of
C. anemae
with relatively slender scrapers, exIII with long fourth seta (short in
C. rectangula
!). Male of
C. anemae
with long slender postabdomen like in
Alona monacantha
(see Sinev, 2004a ), three times as long as wide and with terminal gonopores. Postabdomen of males is therefore completely different from stout male postabdomen with subterminal gonopores in the “true”
C. rectangula
-complex ( Fig. 10D ). For a comparison with related species in Africa, see under Discussion.

Coronatella anemae
n.sp. Adult male (Sudan, Red Sea Hills). A. Habitus; B. First limb, copulatory hook; C. Postabdomen; D. Postabdomen of
C. rectangula = Alona rectangula
(drawing after Alonso 1996 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Variability. ( Figs 7C–E , 8 ). We noted variability in postabdomen shape ( Figs 5K–L , 7C–E , 8A–F ), length of basal spine ( Figs 7C–E , 8G ), main head pore size ( Figs 7A , 8H ), labrum ( Figs 5G–I ), IDL setulation on P1 ( Figs 8I–M , 9D ) and length of fifth seta on exIV ( Figs 9L–M ), both within a single population as between populations (e.g., postabdomen morphology in three localities on Socotra Island ; See Fig. 8 ). Habitus of specimens from Sudan ( Fig. 5A ) and Socotra (e.g., culture from Rewgid, Fig. 5B ), also differed, Sudanese with a more strongly arched body than Socotrans. Labral keel varied from straight to wavy, e.g. between the three Socotran populations and Sudanese ( Figs 5G–I ). Populations from Sudan , UAE and Uzbekistan have a relatively shorter postabdomen ( Figs 5K–L , Fig. 8A ) and stronger denticles on the IDL setae ( Figs 8I–L ) than three Socotran populations ( Figs 8D–F, M ), but also within a population the variability was high (e.g. Qaysoh population, Figs 8D–E ). Specimens raised in the laboratory from Rewgid ( Socotra Island ), had the finest IDL setulation ( Figs 8M , 9D ) and broadest head pores ( Fig. 8H ). We found heaviest setulation ( Fig. 8I ) and shortest postabdomen ( Fig. 8A ) in specimens from Uzbekistan . We consider all these forms to be the same species, other limb characters and males (when present) being completely identical. A useful and “easy” character to recognize
C. anemae
sp. n. externally is the clear ornamentation of the valves, the relatively long postabdomen and the long basal spine, accompanied by long basal spinules.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 11. Records of
Coronatella anemae
n.sp. and the West-African
Coronatella holdeni ( Green, 1962 )
. See text for references. Abbreviations: Soc: Socotra Island; Seych: Aldabra, Seychelles.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Distribution and biology . The range of
C. anemae
sp. n. ( Fig. 11 ) extends from E- and NE-Africa (Lake Chad , Egypt , Sudan , Lake Naivasha in Kenya ) ( Ekman 1904 as
A. bukobensis
; Rey & St-Jean 1969 and Jenkin 1934 as
A. novae-zealandiae
; Delachaux 1917 as
A. poppei
) Eastern Arabia ( UAE ), Uzbekistan and oceanic islands in the Western Indian Ocean ( Socotra , Seychelles ). Can be expected in the Sahara and the whole of the Arabian Peninsula ( Fig. 11 ).
C. anemae
is common in temporary pools on rocks and sand in these highly arid regions where it forms egg-banks. On Socotra , we collected it from dried mud in small limestone rock pools sympatric with the endemic anostracan
Branchipodopsis relictus
in Rewgid (
Van Damme et al . 2004
). Also in small rock holes (Noged) or coastal wetlands (Qaysoh) on the island. In our samples from Sudan , UAE , Socotra and Uzbekistan , we found the species commonly associated with
Alona cambouei .
On Socotra Island ,
C. anemae
colonizes newly constructed rainwater catchments within weeks; there is no other way of reaching these but by wind. In our laboratory cultures, large populations developed three weeks after wetting of dry mud from rock pools, were easy to maintain and produced numerous ephippia. Nine years after collecting, mud from the Socotran localities still produces healthy populations in a few weeks.
C. anemae
is an active animal that feeds by scraping off detrital particles and filamentous algae and is a relatively slow swimmer.
